title: Responding GENERAL DENIAL for a Debt Collection Civil Case, Here is the summary of my latest situation as I was taken to court:
question: -My court case hasn't been gone to default yet, but I have only this week to respond to my summons
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Civil rights,Motions,Sued for debt
answers: It seems that they have taken you to Superior Court instead of Smalls Claims, which is unfortunately quite common. In addition to what the other two attorneys said, you might also want to consider settlement. The amount they are suing you for is very small. If you can settle this for one fourth, it might save you a lot of mental anguish and out of pocket expense, even if you plan to defend yourself. If you go that route and it works, I would suggest that you invest in an attorney to review the settlement agreement before you sign to make sure that your rights are protected.

No, not at all. It is actually common for a defendant to file a General Denial (or Answer which generally denies all allegations). It does not harm your position. It merely forces the plaintiff to present evidence to prove the plaintiff's case.

You should file a general denial, and then hire an attorney. Most of these cases can be defeated by a knowledgable consumer attorney. Don't admit anything in your answer, just check the general denial box.
You need to answer the complaint and request discovery. I handle these cases on a regular basis. Who is the creditor attorney? How much are they suing you for/
